"It was a surprise. It was my last radiation treatment, so I figured go out and get in my car and go home, and I walk out there and they set me up. That was a point that made me feel that people really do care. I mean, I knew that they did, but to have some of those people come out, and not know they would be there, it was nice."

Four months have passed since that day when Kelly received the last of 35 radiation treatments for squamous cell carcinoma, which were interspersed throughout his two-month treatment regimen with three chemotherapy treatments to fight the cancer that infested his upper jaw, cheekbone and nasal cavity. In late August, he received the news he was hoping to hear, that all the suffering was worth it and the cancer no longer present. At least for now.

Pressing forward

During the epoch between hearing that news and that day outside the medical building in Cheektowaga when he gave a tearful, impromptu speech thanking everyone who had come to say goodbye, he did not know what his future held. Yes, the treatments were done, but doctors needed to wait more than two months before they could run tests to determine whether the cancerous cells had been eviscerated. So Kelly did the only thing he knows how to do: He got on with his life, because that's what he has always done, no matter how adverse the situation.

He showed up at end of the Bills mini-camp and gave the team a pep talk before it broke for pre-training camp vacation. He couldn't make it to his annual charity golf tournament, but he was there for his youth football camp in Buffalo, and the one-day camp he holds at St. John Fisher College in Pittsford, teaching the kids the basics of football, and thanking everyone for their remarkable support.

He went to Canton to celebrate Andre Reed's Hall of Fame induction, and when he threw one last pass to Reed on the stage inside Fawcett Stadium at the end of Reed's induction speech, it was the highlight of a wonderful weekend. Life has dealt the 54-year-old Kelly some tremendous pain and unimaginable heartache, yet he somehow remains upbeat, even when death was seemingly knocking at his door just a few short months ago.

"One thing about me that I'm pretty good at is being able to forget things and focus my attention on something else," Kelly said Wednesday following his latest visit to the doctor.

Widely considered by anyone who played with him or against him to be the toughest quarterback there ever was, Kelly is no longer the same man physically. He is gaunt, weakened by the loss of 51 pounds, sometimes cloudy because of the side effects that come from radiation and chemotherapy, and hindered by the pain that still occasionally rages inside his head, not to mention the pain he has long dealt with throughout the rest of his body from a lifetime of playing football.

But this is a man who, despite it all, is now perhaps stronger than he ever was.

Kelly Tough?

The man who coined the phrase and has lived by that credo never truly knew what it meant until this ordeal when, in his darkest moments in a New York City hospital bed, he thought he was going to die.

"Kelly Tough, to me at the beginning, was being physically strong, being able to bounce back from injury, being able to bounce back from something that some people may not be able to; just tough it out," Kelly explained. "But I found out Kelly Tough is more than just the physical part, it's the mental part. Being mentally tough is probably just as important, if not more important."

Kelly was originally diagnosed with oral cancer in June 2013. He underwent surgery at Erie County Medical Center to remove his jaw and most of his teeth. Three weeks later he had been fitted with a prosthetic jaw and false teeth. His doctors told him the procedure had eradicated the cancer.

They were wrong. Several months later, Kelly began to suffer from horrible headaches, and the pain was unlike anything he'd ever experienced. "Pain has been part of my life," he said. "I don't complain about much. When you grow up with six boys you can't show your pain, and if you do, they'll give you another piece of pain."

He went through bottle after bottle of Advil to manage the discomfort, but it was rarely enough. Finally, in March, he told his brother, Dan, that something had to be wrong. So he went in for tests, and it turned out he was right. The cancer had returned, and it was dangerously aggressive.

"I've never had a migraine, but I've heard how painful those are, and I can only relate it to that from what people have told me," he said. "It brought tears to my eyes. If I wasn't on medication I wouldn't have been able to handle it, it was that bad."

Keeping the faith

The news was devastating. How much could one man, one family endure? Jim and Jill had watched their son, Hunter, suffer every day of the remarkable 8 1/2 years he lived before finally succumbing to Krabbe disease in August 2005. And now the Lord that they have given their life to was testing them again.

"I think our family has already experienced the most traumatic thing," said Jill, a magnificently strong and resilient woman who turned 45 last week. "What we went through with Hunter and his life, and his going to heaven, that entire experience of losing a child and watching him suffer every day of his life, that was so traumatic. So this, although it was very, very, very difficult, we've been through so much already that it was just another thing to face. It's not even a 'Why, God?' question, it's a 'How, God?' How do we get through this?"

The answer to Jim and Jill was simple: Have faith, and they have an abundance of it.

Jill became a Christian shortly after Hunter was diagnosed with his fatal neurological disease just four months after his Valentine's Day 1997 birth, which happened to be Jim's 37th birthday. It took a while for Jim to join her.

Much has been documented in the book Jill wrote in 2010, Without A Word, about the marital troubles the couple had and the incredible heartache they suffered throughout Hunter's struggle. Jim did not want to share specifics — it's there to read — but in explaining his decision to become a Christian in 2009, he simply said that he realized he was not the man he wanted to be, and he had to stop hurting Jill and his daughters.

"I wanted to make sure after I was out of town, I could walk through my front door and (my girls could) look at their daddy with respect," he said. "I knew I was losing a lot of that and as a father, you need to accept that responsibility for your kids. And I wanted to make sure that I will see Hunter again, hopefully later than sooner; I was losing all that. I was losing a woman who took care of my son, raising two kids, and I knew I needed to change my life, and thank God I did."

A better man

He looks back at that decision as the definitive turning point of his life. Yes, he was a football hero, the big man on campus, an NFL star whose celebrity transcended the gridiron, a guy who lived a life that many of us would envy. And yet, he learned that he was hollow, a man without a true purpose, until he turned to God.

"I'm 10 times the man I ever was before, a lot better husband, a lot better father, and a lot better person," he said. "When I decided to become a Christian and decided to change my life and just totally quit screwing up, it was like, 'Wow, why didn't I do this before?' No hiding anything, I just felt so much better, not only about myself, but my future, my family. It was awesome, and it didn't take me long to realize that."

Without his faith, the fight for his life that he is now engaged in would have been so much more difficult.

"Little did I know how brutally he would be attacked by this disease," Jill said. "He wasn't going to pull this off with and of his own strength."

Kelly began his stay at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City in early April. He was there for six weeks, and when he went back to Buffalo — to the Cancer Care center — to complete his treatment, he thought he'd only been in New York a couple of weeks. That's how draining it was.

"I don't remember some of the people who visited me, I was on so many different medications, I had 8-10 bags hanging around me and those were gloomy, dark days," he said. "Thank God I had family around me, and friends."

'I couldn't have done it without her'

Most importantly, he had Jill. If he's the toughest quarterback there ever was, then she's in the running for toughest woman there ever was.

"I couldn't have done it without her," he said. "She's been through so much. If there's anybody out there who deserves a medal, it's her. Eight and a half years with Hunter, going through the mental part of your son dying in front of you, and all the things that he went through. Then a short period of time after, all the things I'm going through now, she's been a trouper."

The parade of visitors in New York was constant. Family, friends, old teammates such as Andre Reed, Thurman Thomas, Bruce Smith and Steve Tasker, even old foes like Dan Marino and Boomer Esiason. But then, when it was time for everyone to leave, and he lay there in that bed alone, those were the toughest moments. So Kelly did what he has always done, whether it was rehabbing an injury, or licking his wounds from one of four straight Super Bowl losses: He tried to think positively, even though the stakes were far more daunting.

"If I would have laid there in the bed and thought about all the things that were happening to me and that I was dying, yeah, it would have been tough. But I tried not to. I tried to think of positive things, or I'd watch hunting shows, just to keep my mind off of what I was going through and what my family was going through. How do I turn that negative into a positive? How do I get people around me to think positive? I've always been good at refocusing my attention away from something that was bringing me down."

The pain remains. His strength wavers, depending on the day. There is still concern because with cancer, he said, "There's always a but." But his spirits are good, and Sunday, he will do what he has always done since showing up in Buffalo in 1986 as the cockiest damn quarterback the city had ever seen, hellbent on bringing a championship to a fan base that was starved for one: He'll be at Ralph Wilson Stadium, watching his beloved Bills take on those hated Miami Dolphins.

Through all that he's been through, his life is vivid, it's rich, it's rewarding, and it's filled with people who love him deeply — and that's not just his family, but his old teammates, coaches, and fans across western New York and even the country.

He knows only God knows what's in store for his future, and he's prepared to accept whatever the verdict will be. But rest assured, he's not ready for his life to end, and he's going to fight the same way he always has.

"I still have a lot more things to go through, I'm not out of the dark by any means, but it's a step in the right direction," he said of his latest victory over cancer. "I just take it day by day and I hope one day I can say I feel good, not just be cancer free, but just feel good. I'm just living every day to the fullest, I enjoy myself, I have fun, and I pray every day that it doesn't come back."

A shared struggle

As he did during his career, Jim Kelly had fans during his disease.

Members of an oral, head and neck cancer support group at the UR Medicine Wilmot Cancer Institute sent the former quarterback a card during his recovery. Individuals wrote their own messages and signed their names.

Rita Goodman, a social worker with the Wilmot Cancer Institute, said that seeing a famous person dealing with cancer helps others, particularly those with the same form.

"It promotes awareness," she said. "He had oral, head and neck cancer. That diagnosis is not commonly talked about in the community. It just brings that to the forefront for other patients and survivors in regard to it can affect anybody."

Goodman said members of the group talked about Kelly's battle. "Not only did survivors themselves identify with him, the caregivers identified with his wife and what she's going through as well."

Goodman said that cancer or any serious illness has a way of leveling the playing field between those who are famous and those known only to their family and friends.

"When he finished his treatment, I talked about it with patients," she said. "It really lifted their spirits that he was able to be successful. They recognized the disease didn't take ahold of him. He was able to control his life."

She gave his post-treatment public appearances as examples. "It demonstrates to other people going through treatment and who have been through treatment that there is more to look forward to in life."

— Patti Singer

Steve Tasker remembered going to visit Jim Kelly during his hospital stay in New York City, and the thought that stuck with him as he looked at his dear, suffering friend was, "He went from being Jim Kelly to being a cancer patient."

It was jarring, to say the least, seeing the once-vibrant Kelly laying there in that bed, so weak, so vulnerable, hooked up to tubes, his face contorted in pain, medicated to the point where it was tough to communicate.

"It's pretty rough," Tasker said. "We all know him as being Jim, and his public persona, but you go through that treatment and it knocks the crap out of you."

Not everyone who knows Jim, or cares about him, or is just a fan of his, could visit him. So Jim's wife, Jill, brought him to us using social media. She continually posted updates on her Facebook page and Twitter account, and sent out photos and videos of Jim sharing moments with his daughters Erin and Camryn, or welcoming ex-teammates for visits, because she wanted people to know what Jim was going through, and how he was dealing with it.

Why, you wonder, would Kelly's wife want to open the door on such a terrible time in his life and reveal so many of the details of his life-threatening battle with oral cancer?

Three reasons:

She wanted everyone to remember where he was so that they could pray for Jim. "In sharing, I was in awe by how people rallied in prayer and it wasn't just Bills fans, or people we met through Hunter's Hope (the Kelly's foundation named in honor of their late son). We're talking like Dolphins fans, the Saints and Packers team sending videos, and just the NFL in general."

She wanted a detailed record of everything he went through so their family could look back and remember. "I wanted to be able to remind him, do you remember what you went through and how God pulled you through? You can't forget that you've walked through this."

And, she wanted others who are suffering from cancer or any disease to draw strength from Jim's tough-minded fighting spirit. "We're going to be able to encourage someone who has to go through it," she said. "I felt it was very important to share moments of adversity, and our trials, to encourage someone else."

Jill admitted that at first, Jim was not thrilled that she was going to be sharing so much, but he eventually came to understand Jill's strategic reasons for doing so.

"Jim struggled with this at the beginning; he didn't want anyone to know the details," she said. "But we weren't mindless when we shared things. We believe that we were very strategic with how we shared what Jim was going through."

Some of the pictures were sad, Jim appearing to be in so much discomfort. Others were poignant, such as the ones where Erin and Camryn would snuggle with him in his hospital bed. Others were uplifting because you could see his spirit rise when Thurman Thomas or Andre Reed or Dan Marino would come to visit.

Jill's work behind the video camera also resulted in a wonderfully executed mini-documentary about his fight that aired on ESPN Aug. 3, the morning after Reed was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

Jill gave ESPN much of the video that she shot of Jim receiving treatment, seeing friends, spending tender moments with the girls, and if you saw the final product, you may have cried your eyes out. At the very least, you dabbed them.

Jim looks back on those weeks when he was vomiting almost every day, was being fed through a tube in his stomach, wondering if he was going to walk out of the hospital alive, and he can't thank enough the people who, as Jill said, fed him with encouragement.

"I was blessed to have friends and family come see me, but there were people in the hospital who hadn't had anyone see them for a week and a half, and that's what makes you appreciate what I have, the people I have," Jim said. "And not only the people who came to see me, but the cards, the emails, the letters I got from all around the country, those are things that kept me smiling."

Jill looks back on those weeks, and she is convinced that pulling back the veil of privacy was the right thing to do because she saw in Jim's eyes what it meant to him knowing everyone was pulling for him.

"Jim has always been touted as tough, and he is," she said. "But you find out in a situation like this that you're weak, too, and you can find strength in God. That's humbling, and this has been very humbling. He got to a point where he didn't think he was going to pull this off, and it was going to have to be God and people around him praying him through and feeding him. He had to rely on others, and that's hard for a man in general, but for Jim, it has made him stronger."

From a very young age, when Jim Kelly was first formulating his dream of someday becoming a National Football League star, he recognized one thing about his hometown of East Brady, Pa.

"Basically, what you do in East Brady - although I'm proud to claim it as my hometown - is try to make a better life for yourself," Kelly once said.

So Kelly did, and now he is the most famous person to have ever called East Brady home, and there likely won't be anyone who comes along to bump him off the mountain.

The town sits along the Allegheny River, some 65 miles northeast of Pittsburgh. There aren't -- nor were there ever -- stop lights in East Brady, just stop signs. If you wanted to grab a burger at McDonalds, that was a 30-mile ride. Shopping at a mall? Twenty-five miles.

In East Brady, you made do with what you had, and in the Kelly household -- where Joe and Alice Kelly raised six sons -- there was an abundant supply of love and not much in the way of materialism. Joe Kelly grew up in an orphanage, raised by nuns after his parents had both passed away by the time he was 2. He joined the Navy when he was 17, did a four-year hitch, then came home, met Alice McGinn, married her, and they moved to East Brady to start their family.

Joe worked as a machinist at Daman Industries, and he did odd jobs around town such as carpentry work because feeding six rambunctious boys created a hefty grocery bill.

Alice Kelly maintained the house. Saint Alice they called her, taking care of those boys - oldest to youngest, Pat, Ed, Ray, Jim, and twins Kevin and Danny. In a town where Iron City beer was consumed like water, there was nothing quite like the Kelly six-pack. "We managed to bring her to tears two or three times a week," Kelly wrote in his autobiography, Armed and Dangerous. "It's a wonder she didn't have a nervous breakdown. She always tells people now, 'I wouldn't trade my boys for the world, but there were days I would have gladly given them away.'"

Jim played every sport you could imagine as a kid, and some that a few of the boys from East Brady invented, like jumping off a steel bridge into the Allegheny. From the top, it was 75 feet to the water, which was about 20 feet deep. The winner was the kid who not only survived, but entered the water with the least amount of splash. "Not the smartest thing we've ever done," Kelly said.

By the time he was 7 or 8, Jim was enamored with a far less dangerous pursuit -- football. He played in the county midget league, and when Joe realized the kid had some talent, he became his de facto coach. Jim would come home from school for lunch, and Joe -- also on his lunch break -- had him outside throwing footballs through a tire, and punting and kicking. When Joe was satisfied, then Jim could gobble down a couple of peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, his favorite food.

"All my boys were good athletes, but there was something special about Jimmy,'' Joe Kelly once said. "He had a gift and I didn't want him to waste it. I told him that nothing comes to you unless you work hard at it and pay a price."

When Jim was 10, he made it to the national semifinals of the Punt, Pass and Kick competition, and representing his beloved Pittsburgh Steelers, he flew to San Diego -- a world away from East Brady -- where he finished second in his age group.

The next year, he won the area title again, was invited to Three Rivers Stadium, and there he met his boyhood hero, Steelers quarterback Terry Bradshaw. Kelly shook his hand and said, "I'm going to take your job away, Mr. Bradshaw."

When Kelly entered East Brady High School, he followed in the footsteps of his three older brothers, and eventually, every Kelly wore the Bulldog uniform -- though not as gloriously as Jim.

The oldest, Pat, played at the University of Richmond, and made it to the NFL, drafted in the 15th round in 1974 by the Baltimore Colts where he was a backup linebacker, later moving on briefly to the Detroit Lions, with a stop in the World Football League with Birmingham in between. His career ended just as Jim's legendary epoch was closing at East Brady High, and there was little doubt which Kelly brother was going to likely be the most successful pro.

The Bulldogs went 26-2-1 during Jim's time playing quarterback, punter, placekicker and various positions on defense. Wearing No. 11 -- which the school later retired -- Jim led the team to one conference championship, a share of another, and threw for 3,915 yards and 44 touchdowns. He was an all-state selection as a senior, and became the first player in his conference's history to be chosen to play in Pennsylvania's iconic Big 33 state all-star game.

Fun Fact

Jim Kelly's hometown of East Brady, Pa., is named after Captain Samuel Brady (1756-1795), who fought against Native Americans at that location.

Growing up in a small town like East Brady, Kelly often worried that no one would ever see him play, and maybe he wouldn't get the opportunity to be offered a scholarship to play football in college. And he knew that without a scholarship, it would be difficult for him to go to college given the Kelly family's financial situation.

In truth, the only place he really wanted to go was Penn State. He couldn't have cared less if other schools sent recruiters to East Brady; he was only interested in playing for the Nittany Lions of Joe Paterno.

Well, it's a good thing other schools were eager to have Kelly sign a letter of intent, because Paterno broke Jim's heart. On his official visit to campus, he informed Jim that he wasn't being recruited as a quarterback but rather, a linebacker, and as Kelly said, "it wasn't exactly music to my ears."

For most boys, that wouldn't have been such terrible news. At the time, Penn State was known for its long line of star linebackers, even earning the nickname Linebacker U. It was a badge of honor to carry on that tradition in State College, and several had gone on to play in the NFL, but Kelly -- certainly as tough as any linebacker -- wanted nothing to do with that. He was a quarterback, plain and simple, and that's what he told Joe Pa, thanking the legend for being up front with him before he signed on the dotted line.

Pittsburgh knew all about Kelly's quarterbacking skills and coach Jackie Sherrill was prepared to give him a scholarship, but all his life Kelly had been a Penn State fan which meant hating Pitt, and he couldn't put that aside.

So playing in his home state was out, but thankfully he had other choices, among them football factories like Tennessee and Notre Dame.

In the end, the University of Miami's Lou Saban -- who had served two stints as coach of the Bills, the first in the mid-1960s when Buffalo won back-to-back AFL championships, the second in the mid-1970s when Saban helped turned O.J. Simpson into a superstar -- won the Kelly sweepstakes.

Photos: Jim Kelly through the years

Saban personally came to East Brady, braving a terrible snowstorm, to make his pitch. He reminded Jim to look out the window and think about what the weather was like down in South Florida at that very moment. More importantly, Saban told Kelly he'd be quarterbacking a pro-style offense which was predicated on drop-back, pocket passing, not some of the run-oriented offenses that were popular in the late 1970s.

Another key factor was Saban's contention that Kelly could be the centerpiece of a football revival in Coral Gables. The Hurricanes had been languishing for a decade with just one winning season, but Saban felt Kelly was just the right man to get the program back on track.

Kelly verbally committed that day, but soon took his official visit to Tennessee and was blown away by everything in Knoxville. Big-time program, huge stadium where attendance was never down, great campus, and lots of pretty co-eds.

He was torn until he made his visit to South Florida, and those palm trees, those temperatures, and, yes, even more pretty co-eds, convinced him that Miami was the place to be.

However, that first year, fall of 1978, Kelly was thinking he'd made a huge mistake. Saban, come to find out, wasn't running a pro-style offense but a veer which relied heavily on a mobile quarterback primarily handing off, pitching out, or keeping the ball and running. Kelly was furious, though it didn't matter much because he redshirted as a freshman and didn't play. "Mr. Everything at East Brady to Mr. Nobody at Miami" is how Kelly described what that felt like.

After the 1978 season, Saban -- as Saban was wont to do during his long and nomadic coaching career -- quit Miami to take the job at Army. Kelly wasn't sure if this was a good thing or a bad thing because he really liked Saban, but he wasn't happy with the veer offense, so he considered transferring to Tennessee.

And then Miami hired Howard Schnellenberger, most recently the offensive coordinator of the NFL's Miami Dolphins, who brought Earl Morrall, a former NFL quarterback, along with him to tutor Kelly and the other quarterbacks. Kelly knew right then things were going to change for the better.

It took half the season, but with starter Mike Rodrigue struggling, and the Hurricanes treading water at 3-3, Schnellenberger turned to Kelly during the third quarter of the team's seventh game and told him to get on the field. As it so happened, the Hurricanes were playing Syracuse, and the game was at Kelly's future home, Rich Stadium, because the Orange's new Carrier Dome was under construction back in Syracuse.

That day Kelly entered a game Miami was losing 25-7 and would ultimately lose 25-15, he threw for 130 yards and one touchdown, and Kelly was never a backup again. The following week he made his first start against none other than Joe Paterno and 19th-ranked Penn State, right there in Happy Valley, and if there was ever a sweeter victory in Kelly's life, good luck finding it.

Fun Fact

Though Kelly missed much of his senior season at University of Miami due to a separated shoulder, he finished his career having thrown for 5,228 yards, 376 completions, and 31 touchdowns, then all Miami records, with a mark of 22-8 in games he started.

Did you know?

Jim Kelly was inducted into the University of Miami Sports Hall of Fame in 1992 and his name was added to Miami's Ring of Honor in 2008.

Before Bills fans came to love Jim Kelly, they first hated him.

After making the NFL playoffs in 1980 and 1981, the Bills failed to qualify for the postseason tournament in the strike-shortened season of 1982. With two first-round picks in the 1983 draft, though, there was hope the Bills could quickly add some key pieces and get back on track.

They used the first of those picks, No. 12 overall, on tight end Tony Hunter, a productive player who it was thought would give the Bills a true passing game threat at a position where they'd never really had one. With the second pick, No. 14 overall, they drafted Kelly to be the heir apparent to quarterback Joe Ferguson, who would be entering his 11th NFL season and was nearing the end.

Bills fans were ecstatic. Everyone knew the 1983 draft was loaded with potential star quarterbacks led by the likes of Kelly, John Elway and Dan Marino, and the Bills had managed to draft one of them. Sure enough, those three went on to enshrinement in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

Kelly wasn't so ecstatic. In fact, he was miserable. Thus, unlike Elway and Marino, who began their NFL careers later that fall, Kelly defected to the upstart United States Football League because he simply had no desire to ever step foot in Buffalo, let alone play in what was long considered the snow-belt capital of the world.

The fledgling USFL had opened for business that spring, and the Chicago Blitz had already selected Kelly in the inaugural draft the first week of January. Whereas Kelly was the 14th overall pick of the first round in the NFL, he was picked by Chicago in the 14th round, primarily because it was assumed he'd never agree to play in the league.

Surprise, surprise. When Kelly informed his agents, who were somewhat shocked, that he would consider playing in the USFL if the money was right, they went to work and came up with a dandy of a deal.

With an offer of $2.1 million over four years on the table from the Bills -- nothing to sneeze at back then -- Kelly was prepared to suck it up and sign. But on the day he was in team president Patrick McGroder's office ready to do so, Bruce Allen -- son of former NFL coach George Allen, who was now the general manager of the Blitz -- called One Bills Drive asking to speak to Kelly. Not knowing how damaging it would be to the immediate future of the Bills, the unknowing secretary put the call through, and when Kelly and his agents heard what was on the table, they walked out of McGroder's office and told him they'd get back to him.

Kelly never did.

The USFL was so desperate to get stars like Kelly into the league that Allen said he would gladly give up his rights to Kelly, and allow the quarterback to pick the team he wanted to play for.

Tampa Bay looked inviting, so did Jacksonville, and so did Houston, even though that franchise wouldn't start playing until the 1984 season, which meant sitting out 1983. Kelly flew down to meet with Gamblers owner Jerry Argovitz, and he was blown away by the offer -- $3.5 million over five years, with $1 million up front guaranteed.

That was that. Kelly was going to Houston, Buffalo was soon on its way to back-to-back 2-14 seasons, and if Kelly ever ventured into Erie County, he'd probably be wise to bring a few bodyguards with him.

Did you know?

Tony Hunter, the player chosen two picks ahead of Kelly, played two seasons with Buffalo. He caught 69 passes, including five touchdowns, in 24 games before being traded to the Rams in 1985 for quarterback Vince Ferragamo and a third-round draft choice.

In 1984, his second year in the NFL, Dan Marino put together one of the greatest seasons by a quarterback in NFL history in leading the Miami Dolphins to the AFC championship. Marino became the first to top 5,000 yards in one season, a feat no one accomplished again until Drew Brees in 2008. Marino also threw a record 48 touchdown passes, a standard that stood until Peyton Manning threw one more in 2004, and still ranks as the fourth-highest total of all time.

All of that rendered what Kelly was doing in the USFL largely irrelevant, even though his numbers were even more staggering, because try as they may, the USFL could never compete with the NFL for the nation's attention. Even in a nation that was starved for football.

In his first professional season, Kelly guided the expansion Houston Gamblers to first place in their division with a 13-5 record, and on his way to winning both the rookie of the year and league MVP awards, he completed 370 passes for 5,219 yards (which remained the highest total in pro football history until 2011, when both Brees and Tom Brady surpassed it) and 44 touchdowns, all USFL records that were never broken.

The following year, Kelly sat out the final four regular-season games with a knee injury, but still managed to lead the league in yards passing (4,623), completions (360) and touchdowns (39) while authoring what remains the most prolific single game in pro history, a 574-yard, five-touchdown performance against Steve Young and the Los Angeles Express. That yardage total broke the still-standing NFL record of 554 passing yards set by Norm Van Brocklin in 1950.

It's true that Kelly was playing in an offensive system -- the run-and-shoot which was later made popular in the NFL by Warren Moon and the Houston Oilers -- that was pass first, pass second, and usually pass third. Further, Kelly wasn't going against NFL defenses. There were many excellent players in the USFL who, like Kelly, migrated to the NFL, but top to bottom the rosters weren't nearly as talented, so a player of Kelly's stature could dominate.

Still, Kelly was brilliant, and if they were paying attention -- and you know they were -- Bills fans were seething. During the 1984 and '85 seasons when Kelly was putting up pinball-type numbers, Bills fans were stuck watching in horror the likes of an aging Ferguson, and then Joe Dufek, Matt Kofler, Vince Ferragamo and Bruce Mathison combine for 6,583 yards passing with 27 touchdowns and 61 interceptions as the Bills won four of 32 games.

It was during the 1985 season, though, that Bills fans were offered a glimmer of hope. Thinking they had established a footprint on the sports landscape, the USFL owners made a decision that to this day can only be termed calamitous. They voted to scrap their spring schedule in 1986 and go head-to-head with the all-powerful NFL in the fall. Also, they announced they were filing an antitrust lawsuit against the NFL. In effect, this served as a one-two knockout punch that ended the USFL's outlaw existence.

When a judge ruled in favor of the USFL at trial, but awarded the league just $1 in damages -- trebled to $3 -- the league folded, and just like that all of those players were looking for work, hopefully in the NFL. As for Kelly, per NFL rules, the Bills still had a grip on negotiating rights, and it didn't take long for Kelly to realize it was time to get over his displeasure for playing in the cold weather and sign up to become the savior of a floundering franchise.

Forgive and forget? You betcha. As soon as news broke that Kelly was coming to Buffalo -- for $8 million over five years, then the richest contract in NFL history -- Bills fans suddenly developed a case of amnesia. They welcomed Kelly to town in such a profoundly enthusiastic way that he has never forgotten it, and a love affair between player and city was born.

"It was amazing," Kelly recalled years later. "Not really knowing how people were going to accept me, to a certain point you knew they were excited because they did need a winner here, they needed to start somewhere."

There were fans on virtually all of the overpasses across the Kensington Expressway that took Kelly from the Buffalo airport to a downtown hotel for a press conference the size and scope of which the city had never seen.

"I'm not sure the pope would have got the welcome he got," said the late Kent Hull, a USFL refugee who signed with the Bills the same day Kelly did under far less glamorous circumstances and was Kelly's center all 11 years they played together in Buffalo. "He brought the franchise out of the gutter. At the time that he came to Buffalo, they were needing a central figure to rally around, everybody, and here comes the savior. He really personified the whole franchise, the whole town. Buffalo was a steel town, half of it was shut down, and he came in there and wasn't very successful the first year, but he had enough of that cockiness and arrogance running around in there, and then he got some people around him. All of a sudden we're confident, now I'm going to show you something, and he did."

Did you know?

Kelly appeared on the July 21, 1986 cover of Sports Illustrated wearing a New Jersey Generals uniform. The headline read, "Look out Marino, Montana and Fouts: The USFL's Jim Kelly is ready to prove he's pro football's top gun." Kelly signed with the Bills less than a month later.

When Kelly joined the team, already in their second years were wide receiver Andre Reed and defensive end Bruce Smith, two cornerstone-type players who had been drafted by general manager Bill Polian; Hull and tackle Will Wolford, a 1986 first-round pick, joined an offensive line that included solid pros Jim Ritcher and Joe Devlin; Pete Metzelaars was an up-and-coming tight end and Greg Bell a productive running back; and joining Smith on defense were nose tackle Fred Smerlas, linebackers Darryl Talley and Eugene Marve, and defensive backs Charley Romes and Steve Freeman. Then, nine games into that season came the coach, Marv Levy, who replaced the woeful Hank Bullough.

The Bills finished that first year of the Kelly Era a lowly 4-12, but as Hull said, "We were losing, but he still looked good, so there was always promise with Jim. Then all of a sudden things started getting better, we started getting more people. That stuff is contagious, and it all started with the gunslinger."

Linebacker Shane Conlan and cornerback Nate Odomes were drafted in 1987, Steve Tasker -- who signed the same week that Levy was hired -- began to establish himself as a special teams terror, linebacker Cornelius Bennett was obtained in a blockbuster Halloween night trade, and suddenly the Bills were on the rise. They were in contention in the AFC East until December, finishing 7-8 (one game was lost to the NFL strike), and when running back Thurman Thomas was drafted in 1988, he became the final piece in Polian's masterful rebuild.

The Bills won the first of the six AFC East titles in Kelly's tenure in 1988 and advanced to the AFC Championship Game, where they lost in Cincinnati, 21-10.

In 1989, Kelly was knocked out of a Week 5 game in Indianapolis when right tackle Howard Ballard missed a block. The next day he publicly chastised the young player, and it created a storm of controversy that never subsided the rest of that year.

The Bickering Bills battled each other in the press, yet were still good enough to win the AFC East again with a so-so 9-7 record, then were knocked out of the playoffs by Cleveland in a 34-30 shootout which, as it turned out, proved to be a blessing in disguise.

That day, offensive coordinator Ted Marchibroda unveiled a version of a no-huddle offense, and Kelly threw for 404 yards, his all-time high in the NFL. Kelly was masterful at the breakneck pace, calling his own plays as he flung passes all over the place while the Browns breathlessly tried to keep pace. If not for Ronnie Harmon's clear-cut drop of a sure touchdown pass in the waning seconds, the Bills would have won that game. Instead, they headed into 1990 poised to tear up the NFL.

It didn't happen right away as they mothballed the no-huddle because there was no need to unleash it. They won nine of their first 11 games and were cruising to a third straight division crown. But with Buddy Ryan's defensive monsters from Philadelphia visiting Rich Stadium on the first Sunday in December, Levy gave the go-ahead to use the no-huddle full-time. The Bills scored 24 points in the first quarter on the way to a 30-23 victory, and a revolution was on the way.

They finished the schedule 13-3, then recorded two remarkable home playoff victories over archrival Miami (44-34) and the Raiders (51-3) as Kelly threw for a combined 639 yards and five touchdowns, and would you believe it, the Buffalo Bills were going to the Super Bowl.

Did you know?

Rich Stadium (now Ralph Wilson Stadium) opened in 1973 and did not host a playoff game until Jan. 1, 1989, the day Kelly and the Bills defeated Warren Moon and the Houston Oilers 17-10. Kelly had an 8-1 playoff record as a starting quarterback in Orchard Park, with the lone blemish coming against Jacksonville on Dec. 28, 1996 – the final game of his career.

"Serial Killers of the Super Bowl."

That was what New York Daily News columnist Mike Lupica called the Bills on the eve of their fourth consecutive appearance in the Super Bowl. Harsh, for sure, but there wasn't much to argue when the Bills proceeded to lose Super Bowl XXVIII to Dallas 30-13 at the Georgia Dome on Jan. 30, 1994.

There's a very good chance that Buffalo's streak of four consecutive AFC conference championships will never be matched, and if it is, it seems almost impossible that the Bills' gut-wrenching streak of four consecutive Super Bowl losses would be duplicated.

"There are a lot of guys who played this game who never reached the Super Bowl," linebacker Darryl Talley said. "I was fortunate to have four bites of the apple, though I didn't eat the whole thing. It doesn't bother me that bad anymore."

His teammates feel the same way. Of course it's unfortunate that the Bills never won one, but as the years go by, football experts and fans are recognizing just how remarkable that feat was.

"We're getting so much respect for that now, because it's so hard to do," wide receiver Andre Reed said. "Our team was all about character and what Marv preached with resiliency, and we teach that to our kids and go on in our own lives and we inspire people because of that stuff that happened. If we'd have won four, it would be the same, the only difference would be that we won four. But that didn't happen."

The Bills' best chance, of course, came in the first one, No. XXV in Tampa, when Scott Norwood's last-second 47-yard field goal sailed wide right, enabling the Giants to escape with a 20-19 victory.

"It was something that every one us had dreamed about ever since we were little kids," Kelly said, recalling that initial visit to the NFL's grandest stage. "And there we were. Me and (Tasker) always walked out (of the locker room and down the tunnel) together, and we're walking down there and it was like dominoes. We walked out and by the time we got down to the end of the tunnel we had every single person looking at us. Then we get into the stadium and words can't describe the feeling you get knowing that you worked all your life to get that opportunity to play in the Super Bowl and here we were. And then Whitney Houston sang the national anthem and I'll tell you, if I wasn't playing I probably would have cried. It was pretty emotional. At that time I would have rather been a linebacker than a quarterback because I was so pumped up. I almost felt like I could rip someone's head off."

Unfazed by that heartbreaking defeat, the Bills were even better in 1991. This was Kelly's greatest season, as he worked almost exclusively in the no-huddle and set the franchise record for passing yards with 3,844 and threw 25 touchdowns in leading the Bills to a second straight 13-3 record and a fourth straight AFC East title.

That year, the Bills set team records for points (458), touchdowns (58), first downs (359) and total yards (6,252) that remain unbroken, but after sailing past Kansas City (37-14) and Denver (10-7) in the playoffs, they met up with Washington in Super Bowl XXVI and the Redskins wiped the Bills off the Metrodome field, 37-24 -- a game that wasn't even as close as the 13-point final margin.

It was a miserable day for Kelly as he threw four interceptions. "You only get so many chances," he said afterward. "I'll be 32 next month. Time's running out on me. From the neck down, the whole second half is kind of fuzzy to me. I can remember part of the game, but not all of it. The part I can remember, I didn't like. This is hard to take because we have such a good team. We've come a long way. You hate to say, 'There's always next year.' You get tired of saying that."

Sadly, they would say it at the end of 1992 as well. This time, the Bills had to work a little harder to qualify for a third straight Super Bowl, a feat previously accomplished only by the 1972-74 Miami Dolphins. They failed to win the AFC East for the first time since 1987, losing out to the Dolphins. And in the AFC wild-card game at home against Houston, with Kelly on the sidelines recovering from a knee injury, the Bills fell behind 35-3 early in the fourth quarter.

You know what happened next. The Bills pulled off the greatest comeback in NFL history and won that game behind backup Frank Reich, 41-38 in overtime, then went into Pittsburgh, where the defense played superbly in a 24-3 pounding of the Steelers. Kelly was able to return in time for the AFC Championship Game at Miami, and while he wasn't great, he was good enough to get Steve Christie in position for five field goals and the Bills rolled, 29-10.

Riding such a wave of momentum, the Bills thought they had a great chance against the Cowboys at the Rose Bowl in Super Bowl XXVII. Maybe they would have had they not turned the ball over a record nine times in an embarrassing 52-17 debacle. Kelly was knocked out of the game in the second quarter with the Bills trailing only 14-7, and it all fell apart from there.

"Why me, why me?" Kelly asked afterward. "I said early in the week it would come down to turnovers. Unfortunately, I was right. We couldn't beat a college team with that many turnovers. This loss hurts the most because we had worked so hard and overcome so much to get here. Somebody's got to win and somebody's got to lose, I just wish we could see what it feels like to win."

There would be one more chance. Another AFC East title in 1993 with a 12-4 record, a come-from-behind divisional playoff victory over the Raiders, and a 30-13 whacking of Joe Montana and the Chiefs in the AFC championship game sent the Bills to the Georgia Dome for a rematch with the Cowboys. But, after taking a 13-6 halftime lead, Thurman Thomas lost a fumble early in the third quarter that was returned for a touchdown, and the Cowboys soared to a 30-13 victory, completing Buffalo's golden sombrero of Super Bowl losses.

"We have a lot to be proud of, but we have to figure out what it's going to take to win one," Kelly said. "We're going to keep going until we get it right. What else can you say?"

There was nothing more to say, and there was never a chance to finally get it right.

Did you know?

The Bills' 20-19 loss to the Giants in Super Bowl XXV is the only Super Bowl to be decided by a single point. Six other Super Bowls, including all three of New England's victories, have been decided by three points.

The Bills' streak of making the playoffs six years in a row ended in 1994, with Kelly unable to finish the season due to a knee injury, but they bounced back in 1995 to win the sixth and final division crown of Kelly's tenure.

With a 10-6 record, the Bills had to play in the AFC wild-card round, and during a 37-22 thrashing of Miami in Don Shula's final game, the Bills set a new AFC playoff record with 341 rushing yards. This game, as it turned out, has proven to be the last playoff victory for Buffalo.

The following week, Kelly returned home to western Pennsylvania for a matchup with the Steelers, and the Bills were no match for the eventual AFC champions, losing 40-21 in a game that Bruce Smith missed due to the flu, and Kelly threw for just 135 yards and three interceptions.

When the 1996 season began, everyone knew Kelly was in the final year of his most-recently signed contract, and his future was uncertain. He had clearly begun to decline, as had the team, but there was enough left in the tank to squeeze out another playoff qualification, this time as a 10-6 wild-card team as Drew Bledsoe and the Patriots won the division.

Kelly threw for 2,810 yards, the second-lowest total of his career, and the offense had sputtered throughout the year, yet there wasn't a whole lot of concern heading into the game against Jacksonville, a second-year expansion team that shocked the football world by making the playoffs. The Bills had never lost a postseason game at Rich Stadium, but with the game tied 27-27, Kelly was knocked out of the game with a concussion, and he lost a fumble on the play. The Jaguars pounced on that turnover and turned it into a game-winning field goal by Mike Hollis with 3:07 left to play.

After all he had accomplished in Buffalo, it couldn't have been a worse way for Kelly's career to have ended, losing a playoff game at home to a heavy underdog, and leaving the field on a cart, unable to finish the game.

A little more than a month later, Kelly made it official: He was done, announcing his retirement in a lavish press conference held inside the team's practice facility, televised live on local TV as well as ESPN.

Several years later, he reflected on what it meant to be the quarterback of the Bills.

"I always knew, and I was always brought up believing, that you can't do things alone," Kelly said. "I know I was a key ingredient because of the position I played, and I knew that in order for the Bills to go anywhere they had to have a top quarterback. But I also take great pride in knowing that I was one of our leaders on the team. Early on I made mistakes, just like most people do. There were things I wish I could take back that I can't. I've always been taught that it's what you do about the negatives, never dwell on them, learn from them, and move on. I was able to get people to not so much follow me, but join me, and I had enough people to join me."

Did you know?

Kelly owns the Bills career records for passing completions (2,874), attempts (4,780), yards (35,467), touchdowns (237), average yard per attempt (7.42) and 300-yard games (26).

At the height of his football celebrity Jim Kelly was one of the most eligible bachelors in Buffalo and could have had almost any woman he wanted. Jill Waggoner, just 21 years old in the summer of 1991, was the one he wanted.

In her book Without A Word, Jill wrote about the circumstances that led to her and Kelly meeting, falling in love, having a child, and marrying.

Kelly lived in a huge house in the affluent Hillsboro neighborhood of Orchard Park, a short ride away from Rich Stadium, and it became party central on Sunday nights following Bills home games. The team would gather there along with anyone else who had been able to wrangle an invitation, and if you didn't have one, you weren't getting past the doorman, Kelly's good buddy and bodyguard Big Ed. The parties became legendary as famous athletes and beautiful women talked, drank, danced and, well, you get the picture.

One night Jill and a girlfriend had been invited by friends of Jim's, and she couldn't believe the scene when she walked through the doors and saw her future husband -- "a notorious partier," as she described him in her book -- in action. Eventually, someone introduced Kelly to the two young girls, and Jill described him as being "very gracious and polite" and recalled his complimenting her on her "beautiful green eyes." Jill figured that would be the extent of her meet and greet with the famous host, but she said he flirted with her the rest of the night and, at the end, asked for her phone number.

She said no, but about a week later, the industrious Kelly put one of his people on it and tracked her down at her place of work, asked her out on a date, and she agreed.

From that moment on, they were a couple, and a lengthy courting began. After a year and a half Jill moved to south Florida to pursue a career in television marketing and production, but being in a long-distance relationship wasn't working for either of them, and she made the decision to move back to western New York and into Kelly's home in May of 1994.

Within a few months Jill was pregnant with their first child, Erin Marie, and she feared that Kelly would be upset by the news. Instead, he was thrilled, and a few months before Erin was born, Kelly asked Jill to marry him while the two dined in a private room at Ilio DiPaolo's restaurant in Blasdell. The three-carat diamond ring was presented to Jill on the top of a heart-shaped cake made personally by Dennis DiPaolo that read "Will You Marry Me?"

Erin was born in early 1995, and her parents were married on May 18, 1996, a wedding that was the social event of the year in Buffalo. More than 600 guests were present inside St. Christopher's in suburban Buffalo, hundreds of others were outside the church trying to catch a glimpse, and then the reception was held at the New York State Armory in the heart of the city where guests were required to present a numbered invitation to gain entrance.

Jill wrote in her book that the marriage did not get off to a great start because in cleaning out the house in the summer months after the wedding, she stumbled across upsetting remnants of Jim's bachelor life. Also, Jim seemed uninterested in his new life as a husband and father and spent most of the time before the 1996 season -- his first as a married man and his last as an NFL quarterback -- on the road making appearances or just getting together with buddies for golf or fishing trips.

She hoped that news of a second pregnancy -- which the doctors determined had occurred while the Kellys were honeymooning in Italy -- might reel Jim back in, but she had her doubts.

Hunter James Kelly was born on Jim's 37th birthday, Feb. 14, 1997. And before he was four months old, the Kellys learned the terrible news that he was suffering from Krabbe Leukodystrophy, an inherited neurodegenerative lysosomal enzyme disorder affecting the central and peripheral nervous systems that typically kills its victims in the first 13 months.

Nothing in Jim and Jill's life would ever be the same again after the diagnosis. It was a devastating day, and for the next eight-plus years, as Hunter demanded constant medical assistance from an army of caregivers, the Kellys' marriage faded to the background, and Jill wrote that she often doubted whether Jim truly loved her, and questioned her own love and commitment to him.

What the Kellys endured in these years tugs at the heartstrings, and while there were certainly some happy times -- topped by the healthy birth of their third child, Camryn, in June 1999 -- there were also tremendously difficult and sad times as they felt powerless to help Hunter while always living in fear that he could die at any moment.

Jill turned to Jesus Christ in 1998, and by becoming a devout Christian, she found peace and strength and hope that carried her through the toughest times. After initially resisting, Jim saw the light and he, too, dedicated his life to Christ after confessing to Jill that throughout their marriage he had been unfaithful to her almost from the beginning. When Jim turned to Christianity, it was probably a shock to most of those who knew him as the swashbuckling quarterback with the larger-than-life personality and celebrity lifestyle, but he admits now that the moment he decided to do it, "I felt forgiven, I felt free."

Three years after Hunter passed away in 2005, Jim and Jill renewed their wedding vows, and it was as if he had pushed the reset button on his life. It is their faith that guides them today as Jim battles the toughest opponent he's ever faced: Cancer.

Did you know?

Jill Kelly grew up in Attica, Wyoming County, and is a 1987 graduate of Notre Dame High School in Batavia.

Jim Kelly and toughness go together about as well as peanut butter and jelly, his sandwich of choice as a youngster growing up in tiny East Brady, Pa. The majestic spirals that he threw, so powerful that they seemed to cut through the bitingly cold Orchard Park air with a smile, will never be forgotten. Nor will the sight of Kelly, after every touchdown pass he tossed at Rich Stadium, pointing up to his luxury box where his family sat every Sunday and giving them a heartfelt salute.

He was brash. He had swagger. He had an absolute confidence in himself, mistaken at first as arrogance when he first blew into Buffalo in the summer of 1986 and was charged with rejuvenating not only a sad-sack football franchise but a sagging city. But more than anything, it was Kelly's toughness that set him apart from almost every quarterback who ever played the game.

His Bills coach, Marv Levy, has said he was "the toughest player I ever coached."

Oh, Kelly was tough, there's no denying it. But he had nothing on his son, Hunter, a little boy who raised the toughness meter to astronomical standards, and Kelly made sure everyone knew that on the afternoon in 2002 that he was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

"It has been written throughout my career that toughness is my trademark," Kelly said of Hunter, then 5 1/2 years old. "Well, the toughest person I've ever met in my life is my hero, my soldier, my son, Hunter.''

Hunter was born on Valentine's Day 1997, a seemingly healthy 7-pound, 14-ounce boy. He was supposed to have died somewhere around Valentine's Day 1998. Instead, serving as the ultimate definition of what it means to be Kelly Tough, Hunter graced the world with his presence until August of 2005. You want to talk about tough? Hunter endured an unfathomable existence, yet he fought like a Kelly, and when the miracle that was his life finally ended, he had lived longer than any child born with the disease that afflicts one out of every 100,000 live births.

The news of Hunter's plight not only rocked the Kellys, it affected the entire community. Jim was a hero, Buffalo's connection to the big time, the Hall of Famer, Mr. Buffalo Bill. If he was hurting, so, too, were western New Yorkers, and millions of tears were shed during the epoch that was Hunter's life. The Kellys were always very public regarding Hunter in the hope that, as Jill said, "putting a face on this horrible disease" would help increase efforts to find a cure. They appeared on Oprah and the Today show, People magazine did a huge spread, and so did several other publications, and their fundraising efforts through the Hunter's Hope foundation that they established in 1997 have been the stuff of legend.

It was all rather amazing how this little boy, this soldier, his father's hero, had such an impact and left such a lasting impression on everyone who came in contact with him, and even those who never knew him, because his story was so powerful, so heart-wrenching.

Hunter never spoke, he never smiled, he never walked, he never threw the football around in the backyard with his famous father who had long dreamt of doing that if he was so fortunate to have a son. But Hunter lived, and he inspired, and he meant more to his father than anything Jim -- the toughest football player of his generation and many others -- ever accomplished on the gridiron.

Did you know?

The Hunter's Hope Foundation was founded by Jim and Jill Kelly in 1997, shortly after their son, Hunter, was diagnosed with Krabbe Leukodystrophy. For more information on Hunter's Hope, go to huntershope.org.

Jim Kelly's football achievements, as magnificent as they were, also pale in comparison to the tireless work he and his wife Jill have done with their foundation, Hunter's Hope, which they established in 1997 as a way to raise money for research to find a cure for the horrible disease which afflicted, and later took the life of, their son.

But long before Hunter was born and Hunter's Hope became a lifelong commitment, Kelly was fully aware of the responsibilities he would shoulder as the team's star quarterback. When he landed in Buffalo in August of 1986, he knew his main priority was to help turn the sagging Bills franchise into a winner, and with that machine gun of an arm -- yes, remember the Machine Gun Kelly poster? -- he was well-equipped to do that. But being a professional athlete, especially one at the top end of the pay scale, is about so much more than production on the field. When you become the face of a franchise, as Kelly did, you have an inherent obligation to become a pillar of the community you represent, and not only give back what you can to the people who help to pay your salary, but to help those less fortunate.

Some athletes never get this. Kelly got it from day one. Almost as soon as that limo whisked him from the airport to his introductory press conference where he signed his five-year, $8 million contract, he established his Kelly For Kids Foundation, defining the mission statement as follows: To serve disadvantaged and disabled youth in western New York through a variety of grants raised through the year. Now coming up on three decades of existence, Kelly For Kids has distributed more than $5 million to local charities, though the main beneficiary now is Hunter's Hope.

Hunter's life could not be saved, but the Kelly's fervent wish is that Hunter's Hope can help save the lives of other children by advocating mandatory universal newborn screening in every state, and to fund research efforts that will identify new treatments, therapies, and ultimately a cure for Krabbe disease and other leukodystrophies. The foundation also provides monetary gifts for families to partially cover travel expenses related to treatment, and it helps cover the cost of Hunter's Homes, three homes near Duke Medical Center in Durham, N.C., where families stay free of charge while going through the Cord Blood Transplant process.

All of this takes money, and the Jim Kelly Celebrity Golf Classic, which was held for the 28th consecutive year in early June 2014, is the primary fundraiser for Kelly For Kids. Originally played at Brierwood Country Club outside Buffalo, it has been held since 2006 at Terry Hills Golf Course in Batavia.

The event begins with the Sunday night VIP Gala dinner at the Adams Mark Hotel in downtown Buffalo, typically attended by about a thousand people, one of the biggest charity events of the year in western New York.

On Monday, everyone heads to the golf course for a long day of golf, food, raffles and camaraderie. Each foursome -- of which there were nearly 50 this year -- is joined by a celebrity from sports or entertainment, and the list through the years is impressive. Among the tournament alumni are former Bills' greats Thurman Thomas, Bruce Smith, Andre Reed, Joe DeLamielleure, Fred Smerlas and Steve Tasker; former NFL stars Dan Marino, Bernie Kosar, Archie Manning, Anthony Munoz and Doug Flutie; actors Daniel Baldwin, Chris McDonald and Jamie Farr; and ESPN's Chris Berman.

Another key component under the vast umbrella of Kelly For Kids is the Jim Kelly Football Camp, which not only raises money but also provides young aspiring football players the chance to learn from a man who was a hero to many of their fathers, maybe even a few grandfathers.

The football camp was first held in 1988 with 325 campers on hand listening intently to the then young quarterback of the up-and-coming Bills teach them lessons about football, family, health and nutrition, drug awareness, sportsmanship and teamwork. Each year the camp has grown and today, approximately 500 campers per year take part, and Kelly has never missed one -- even in July 2014, when he was barely three weeks removed from his last chemotherapy and radiation treatments. In the last few years, the camp has been held in the Buffalo area, but Kelly has conducted a special one-day camp at St. John Fisher College, home of the Bills' annual training camp since 2000.

Kelly has also benefited from his fame on the field as a businessman off the field. During his playing days he opened a nightclub in downtown Buffalo called Network, along with an adjoining sports bar called the Sports City Bar & Grill, that were popular hangouts in the early- to mid-1990s. However, they didn't last long, and when they were going out of business, the companies that operated the restaurants filed for bankruptcy, leaving creditors unpaid, and Kelly was vilified for this. Outside of the long lines one had to stand in to get into the clubs when they were first opened, the most memorable thing that happened there was a 1994 brawl that saw six members of the Hartford Whalers NHL team -- Chris Pronger, Pat Verbeek, Geoff Sanderson, Marc Potvin, Mark Janssen and Todd Harkins, and assistant coach Kevin McCarthy -- get arrested.

At one time he was a pitchman for Wegmans -- remember the WPOP commercials? -- and he also did ads for Toys R Us, The United Way, and several other companies. More recently, he founded Jim Kelly Inc., a company which produces the MyFanClip line of all-purpose clips bearing team logos. The company has procured licensing agreements with the NFL, MLB, NHL, NASCAR, and several NCAA institutions, with proceeds earmarked to benefit the Hunter's Hope Foundation.

Did you know?

At one point in 2001, Kelly had a relationship with supermarkets Tops and Wegmans at the same time. He had a personal relationship with Tops and, because Wegmans was a training camp and team sponsor of the Bills, was involved with a ticket sales campaign through Wegmans.

Where else would you rather be than right here, right now? That was one of Marv Levy's favorite axioms, and on the afternoon of Aug. 3, 2002, there was no place Levy would have rather been than at Fawcett Stadium in Canton, Ohio to present the greatest quarterback in Bills history for induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

There had been many great days in the town that gave birth to the NFL, but the 2002 enshrinement ceremony certainly ranks as one of the greatest. When it was announced in late January that Kelly had been voted into the Hall in his first year on the ballot, the folks at Kelly Enterprises informed Canton officials that, to borrow a phrase from a famous movie about a shark, "You're gonna need a bigger boat."

Since the induction of the first class in 1963, the ceremony was held on the steps leading to the front door of the Hall, and the spectators congregated in the area out front. But with Kelly in the class, Canton was going to be inundated with Bills fans, and there was no way they were all going to fit.

Thus, the ceremony was moved next door to Fawcett Stadium where the annual Hall of Fame game was played, and it was a good thing because there were tens of thousands of blue-shirted Bills fans there to fete their favorite son. It has remained there ever since.

"Is there anyone here from Buffalo today?" Levy said as he stepped to the podium, producing a titanic roar. "Is there anyone back in Buffalo today?"

Levy, who had been enshrined just a year earlier, then delivered an ever-eloquent speech.

"You know, in order to win in the NFL you've got to have ability and sometimes you gotta have some luck, too," Levy said. "Well, Jim Kelly had ability and much more. I was the one who had the luck because from the very first day I became coach of the Buffalo Bills I was keenly aware of what a special player, and what a special person Jim Kelly was. How lucky can a guy get?"

Levy went on to add, "If you ask this specific coach who he wants to line up at quarterback for his team, I'd answer by pointing, right there, No. 12, Jim Kelly. Never mind his eye-popping statistics, he never cared about them anyway. Jim cared about winning, and he was a winner. He cared about his team and about his teammates. He cared about his wonderful family, and about our loyal and enthusiastic Buffalo Bills fans. He cared about his community, and he showed it. Never mind about his arm, it was great, but what was really noteworthy about Jim was his heart. Jim Kelly's heart was as stout as a nose tackle's butt."

By the time Kelly stepped up, the crowd was primed, and Kelly delivered a speech commensurate with the thrilling touchdown drives he once directed for the Bills. First, it took a minute for the crowd to stop cheering, and Kelly quipped, "C'mon now, I only have seven minutes to give my speech!"

He then knocked it out of the park with the way he delivered the speech, and the points that he made throughout. Early, he began with, "Boy, my life has been a series of crossing patterns involving family and football and I can't remember a time when football hasn't been a part of my life. But, I can tell you I would have never made it this far without the constant love, support and dedication of my family, my friends and you, the Buffalo Bill fans, the greatest in the NFL."

He systematically thanked his parents, his five brothers, and some of his coaches along the way, before getting to the Buffalo portion of his life.

"And then, I made the greatest decision of my life; I became a Buffalo Bill," he said. "I can't think of a better owner to play for than Ralph Wilson, and his place in this Hall is waiting (which turned out to be prophetic). He guaranteed me that he would provide the weapons for the Bills to be a Super Bowl team, and boy did he ever."

Kelly then went through the list, mentioning Thurman Thomas, Bruce Smith, Andre Reed, James Lofton, Steve Tasker, Darryl Talley, Jim Ritcher, Will Wolford, Pete Metzelaars, Don Beebe, Kenny Davis, Frank Reich, Kent Hull, Alex Van Pelt and Ruben Brown.

He thanked Levy, several assistant coaches, general managers Bill Polian and John Butler, many members of the Bills' administrative staff, and he even gave a shout out to long-time Buffalo News columnist Larry Felser, who made the case for Kelly -- not that one really needed to be made -- for his induction in the Hall of Fame voting room.

Finally, his family, who he addressed as they sat in the warm sunshine in the front row, his wife, Jill, their daughters Erin and Camryn, and their son Hunter. At this point, Hunter was five, and Jim and Jill knew that he understood where he was, and what was happening. They also knew they had been blessed that Hunter had beaten the odds and lived this long, four years longer than the doctors originally thought he would.

"Since the day I was selected (in January 2002), I prayed to God that my son would be here with me today," Kelly said. "God has granted me that blessing. It has been written throughout my career that toughness is my trademark. Well, the toughest person I've ever met in my life is my hero, my soldier, my son, Hunter. I love you, buddy. Thank you, Canton, thank you Buffalo and God bless."

There were cheers, yes. And there were tears, Many of them. What a special day it was, indeed.

Did you know?

Jim Kelly is one of 10 members of the Buffalo Bills family to be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame. The others are: Joe DeLamielleure; Marv Levy; James Lofton; Andre Reed; Billy Shaw; O.J. Simpson; Bruce Smith; Thurman Thomas and Ralph Wilson Jr.

The headaches were becoming unbearable, and for a man who was so used to dealing with pain and shrugging it off like it was nothing, it was newsworthy that Jim Kelly felt the need to have tests done to discover the cause of the terrible discomfort he was dealing with in the spring of 2014.

Never mind 11 years of violence in the NFL. This is a guy who had survived a single-prop plane crash into the Bering Sea while on a hunting trip in Alaska. Headaches were knocking him to his knees?

Kelly has endured countless surgeries due to all the football injuries he suffered -- part of the roll call including two plates and 10 screws in his back, another plate and six screws in his neck. His knees, ankles and shoulders all have surgical scars, as does his abdomen, where he had a double hernia. He's had broken fingers, several concussions and pulled muscles.

That was all before things really got tough for him, when he was diagnosed with oral cancer in May of 2013. He underwent a procedure where part of his upper jaw and several teeth were removed, which doctors believed eradicated the cancer, and he was fitted with a prosthetic jaw complete with six false teeth. In the aftermath, he underwent six root canals on the teeth that are still his originals, as doctors tried to piece the inside of his mouth back together.

Kelly took on the big 'C' exactly as you would expect - with bravery, confidence, toughness, and faith. "We are all faced with challenges and unfortunately I've gone through more than the average person, but oh well," Kelly said. "Ups and downs, that's my life. But it's what you do about it that matters. No matter what I did in football, my family life, you never give up. ... You move on and make tomorrow a little better than today."

He said fighting cancer was just "another river to cross", a nod to the Super Bowl years when Bill Polian used to say that about the Bills as they marched through obstacles season after AFC championship season. And just like he did so often on the field, it seemed Kelly was winning. Within three weeks of his surgery, doctors told Kelly he was cancer free, and a collective sigh could be heard blowing through western New York. Their guy was going to be OK.

But on the road to apparent recovery, those rivers were getting deeper to negotiate. The headaches throughout the late fall and winter into 2014 - worse than a migraine, he said - were an indication to him that all was not well, and finally, he couldn't take it anymore. He went through a battery of tests, and the news was not good. The cancer was back in the form of microscopic tumors inside his face, having taken root in the maxillary sinus cavity and adjacent tissues, and now spreading dangerously up his infraorbital nerve, close to the carotid artery.

At first, doctors thought they could surgically remove the tumors, but they opted instead to treat the cancer with radiation and chemotherapy. He spent six weeks at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City, and then concluded his treatment at the Cancer Care of Western New York in Cheektowaga. When the process ended in early June, he had lost 51 pounds, and into August he still could not eat, his nourishment coming via a feeding tube in his stomach.

Yet Kelly wasn't going to let cancer prevent him from doing the things he covets. He showed up at the end of the Bills' mini-camp and gave the team a pep talk before they broke for pre-training camp vacation. He couldn't make it to his golf tournament, but he was there for his youth football camp, teaching the kids the basics of football, and thanking everyone for their remarkable support. He went to Canton to celebrate Andre Reed's Hall of Fame induction, and he was on the sidelines when the Bills played their first preseason game at renovated Ralph Wilson Stadium, days after learning that the chemo and radiation treatments had worked, and there was no sign of the cancerous tumors.

When you have cancer, there isn't a day that goes by when you don't think about it. Cancer came back once to Kelly, and who knows what the future holds because this disease is so unpredictable. But for now, Kelly's bustling life continues on, and while cancer has proved to be his toughest opponent, perhaps cancer is learning that Kelly Tough is one of its toughest opponents, too.

Did you know?

Jill Kelly has used social media extensively during her husband's battle with cancer, using Instagram, Twitter (with popular hashtags #PrayersforJK and #KellyTough) and Facebook to share updates, pictures and messages of faith.

Feb. 14, 1960: James Edward Kelly was born in East Brady, Pa., one of his six Kelly sons born to Joe and Alice Kelly.

Sept. 1974 through March 1978: Kelly starred for East Brady High School, throwing for 3,915 yards and 44 touchdowns and leading the Bulldogs to a 26-2-1 record during his three years as the starting varsity quarterback. He also averaged 23 points and 20 rebounds in basketball as a senior.

August 1978: Heads to the University of Miami after accepting a scholarship from Hurricanes coach Lou Saban, the former coach of the Bills. He red-shirted that first year and never played for Saban, who stepped down after the season to take the head coaching job at Army.

Oct. 27, 1979: With the new Carrier Dome under construction in Syracuse, the Orangemen played one of their "home" games at Rich Stadium in Orchard Park and defeated the University of Miami, 25-15, in front of only about 8,000 fans. Kelly entered the game in the third quarter and threw for one TD and passed for a two-point conversion. He completed 7 of 17 passes for 130 yards in the first extended action of his collegiate career.

Nov. 3, 1979: In the first start of his college career, Kelly led the Hurricanes to a 26-10 victory over Penn State at Beaver Stadium in State College, Pa. It was a sweet day for Kelly because Nittany Lions coach Joe Paterno had recruited Kelly heavily, but as a linebacker, thinking Kelly couldn't play quarterback at the Division I level. Kelly threw for 280 yards and 3 TDs.

Oct. 31, 1981: Kelly did it again to Paterno. The No. 1-ranked Nittany Lions traveled to the Orange Bowl and Kelly led the Hurricanes to a 17-14 upset victory, throwing an 80-yard TD pass in the process.

Sept. 18, 1982: Kelly's college career came to an end when he suffered a serious shoulder injury in a game at Virginia Tech.

April 26, 1983: With the second of their first-round draft picks, the Bills selected Kelly No. 14 overall, two picks after they'd chosen Notre Dame tight end Tony Hunter. Watching the draft on ESPN with his parents at the Akron, Ohio, home of attorney Ken Weinberger, Kelly wasn't too thrilled with being picked by the Bills.

June 9, 1983: Ending a couple months of intrigue, Kelly decided to spurn the Bills and signed with the Houston Gamblers of the USFL. Owner Jerry Argovitz signed Kelly to a four-year contract that was reportedly worth between $4 and $5 million, making him the league's second-highest player behind Herschel Walker. "There are risks in doing what I'm doing, but I made up my mind," Kelly said. "Everybody has to take a risk once in a while. I'm happy I did it and I won't regret it. I always wanted to play in the NFL, but right now, the USFL is the same as the NFL. It's a business now."

July 2, 1984: Was named the USFL's player of the year after throwing for 5,219 yards and a single-season pro football record 44 touchdowns for the Gamblers. Upon receiving the award, Kelly said: "I cried when Buffalo drafted me (in the 1983 draft). Well, maybe I didn't cry, but it wasn't one of the greatest things that happened in my life. You can't be a great quarterback in snow and 30 mph winds." Bills management wasn't pleased by his statements. "I think it's unfortunate that a moment of considerable personal triumph for him turned into a little bit of an unfortunate statement," said Bills general manager Terry Bledsoe.

Feb. 1, 1985: Interviewed in Houston, Kelly reiterated his disdain for playing in Buffalo. "If Buffalo were my last option, I would go there, but every quarterback wants to play in warm weather," he said. "Of all the places that should have a domed stadium, it's Buffalo. If Buffalo plans on getting anybody, if you ever want a chance of having a winning team, tell Ralph Wilson he's going to have to spend some money."

May 27, 1985: Suffered a season-ending knee injury playing for the Houston Gamblers in the USFL. That ended any speculation that he could join the Bills for the 1985 season.

July 21, 1986: In a Sports Illustrated story, Kelly said that with the merger of the Gamblers and New Jersey Generals, thus pairing him with Herschel Walker, the new Generals' offense would be unstoppable. "With my receivers and Herschel, we could score 35 points on the Chicago Bears. No question," Kelly said.
